transcripts.text: You can't live in this world today and not be curious.  In fact, if ever there was a time to hear from more than the usual suspects, it's now.  This is The Carlos Watson Show.  Maybe we'll surprise you.  Maybe you'll be mad at us sometimes or inspired.  Not only do I hope people will see more with the show, but I hope they'll do more and be more.  People, the good stuff starts now.
I'm a risk taker.

Is California Congresswoman Karen Bass about to become Joe Biden's running mate?  Would you be okay with that level of scrutiny and spotlight?  The chair of the Congressional Black Caucus opens up about the tragic loss of her daughter and how it bonded her to Joe Biden.
It changes you forever, that's for sure.  Both of us were in public life, so you don't have an opportunity to grieve privately.
What would absolutely surprise those folks who think they know Congresswoman Karen Bass?  The unusual answer to that and the danger that is Donald Trump.
Whenever he's down, he finds somebody of color to kick.
Congresswoman Bass, thank you so much for joining me on the show.  Always excited to be with you.
Thank you.  Same here.  And congratulations on the show.
Congresswoman, it has made me smile to hear your name bandied about as a potential vice presidential nominee.  How has that made you feel?

Well, you know, those those issues have to be referred to the campaign, unfortunately.  But, you know, the idea that people would discuss me in that context, of course, is very humbling, very humbling.  At this moment in our country, you know, we have just been traumatized for three and a half years, multiple times a day.  And now look at the situation that we're in.  In four months, 127,000 Americans have vanished.  They died.  And we have a president that hasn't missed a beat.
I think what happens is it's going to go away.  This is going to go away.  As far as the coronavirus, as you say, I think we've done some amazing things.

Every day I see that number go up, and I just think about all those lives lost and how many of them were not needed.  So I said to my people, slow the testing down, please.  I'm not sure he thinks about them, cares about them.
Yeah, the cities, unfortunately, that are in trouble are all run by Democrats.
I think of the racial turmoil that he formats every single day.  Why are African Americans still dying at the hands of law enforcement in this country?
So are white people.  What a terrible question to ask.
But it's like, whenever he's down, he finds somebody of color to kick.
This left-wing cultural revolution is designed to overthrow the American Revolution.
Anything that I can do to help what I'm going to claim is future President Biden, anything I can do to help our country get back on track, I'm going to be right there in any capacity possible.
Congresswoman, for those who don't know a little bit of your backstory, were you always headed for politics if I had met you as a young woman?

Yes, I was involved in politics since a child.  But I view politics as way beyond running for office.  So what I never envisioned was running for office.  I've always been politically involved, always involved in issues per se, but not necessarily campaigns.  I mean, I've really been involved since I was about 13 or 14.
And what kind of issues that 13 and 14 year old Karen, I'm trying to envision her, what kind of 13 or 14 year old Karen, what was she into?

Well, I was really interested at an even younger age in the civil rights movement and watching it on TV.  You know, my father would watch the news every night and I'd sit next to him and watch the news and ask him questions.  You know, I had a tough time understanding Jim Crow in the South and the response that those older people, of course, they were college students, but they were older people to me, were getting food dumped on their head and beaten and hosed and all of that.  It was very strange for me.  But when I was 14, I actually did get involved in my first campaign.  It was Bobby Kennedy's presidential campaign.  And I signed up my mother to be a precinct captain, but I went out and walked the precinct.  And then when King was assassinated and Kennedy was assassinated, that was pretty traumatic for a young teenager.  And I kind of lost a lot of hope.  and then the Vietnam War was there and I became an anti-war activist and went off to college and from there got involved in international issues, but domestic issues as well.  And, you know, it actually came up for me when I went to George Floyd's funeral.  And I looked up at his portrait and I saw he was born in 1973.  And in 1973 was when I first started working on police abuse, because I was involved in an organization called the Coalition Against Police Abuse.  And it just made me realize that was 47 years ago, you know?

The Justice and Policing Act establishes a bold, transformative vision of policing in America.  Never again should the world be subjected to witnessing what we saw on the streets in Minneapolis, the slow murder of an individual by a uniformed police officer.  The world is witnessing the birth of a new movement in our country.  This movement has now spread to many nations around the world, with thousands marching to register their horror at hearing the cry, I can't breathe.  People marching to demand not just change, but transformative change.

Congresswoman, I hope this doesn't sound funny, but you have a depth and a quality of confidence about you that I don't see in many people in any arena, in many areas.  Am I right that that's there?  And if so, where did that come from?

I think my confidence comes from my commitment and my very clear commitment to issues that are outside of myself.  But also I'm a risk taker.  And so when I started Community Coalition, I had absolutely no idea what I was doing.

Now, how did you finally make the leap to actually run for office?  Because I can hear your heart and I can see your spirit and I can see that you enjoyed what you were doing from 68 all the way forward.  So when did you finally make the plunge to put your name on the ballot?

The Community Coalition, when we started the organization, the reason we started it is because for me, crack cocaine was a health issue.  And I saw us criminalize a health issue.  And I was very distressed by that.  And so I wanted to start an organization to try to figure out how to deal with crime in a way that didn't result in mass incarceration.  It was so obvious that's what we were going to have.  The Congresswoman at the time, who was sitting in this seat, called me up and told me that I had been in the community long enough and I needed to be in the state legislature.  And I was intrigued when she told me there were no African-American women in the state legislature.  So I realized that the same issues I was working on in South Central Los Angeles, I could work on at the state capitol in another level.

You know, that's actually a profound point you just brought up and something that we've talked a lot about at Ozzy, which is should there be new requirements?  Like if we were starting the Republic afresh or if we were doing a reset of the country, a new constitutional convention, how would you change the laws around who can run and what's required?  And I mean that both as a serious and as a creative question as someone who's had an opportunity to serve in state legislature and the national legislature.

Well, you know, it gets tough because I don't know where you put, I mean, you know, the belief in democracy that anybody can run.  I mean, we do have a member who's going to be coming in in January who's too young right now.  He won his primary election.  So by the time the general election happens, he'll be old enough, which means he'll be 25.  He's 24 right now.
Wow.

So, you know, you get it.  Where do you have the limit?  I mean, it would make sense to say everybody should have a college degree, but how much college and what did you study and where did you go?  So I don't know.  I think it's really a question for voters to decide versus if we put something in a constitution.

She was a 60s wild child, then an activist, now perhaps the most interesting member of Congress as we speak.  Karen Bass is at the forefront of the new revolution that's washing over our country.  Congresswoman Bass, thanks again for joining us.  Now, who have been your heroes over the years?

Well, you know, a lot of ordinary people.  And unfortunately, most of them are long gone.  You know, definitely starting with my parents, no question about that.  My father was a letter carrier.  My mother was a homemaker.  But I think they instilled in us a set of values.  Now, my parents never wanted me to be politically active, never wanted me to run for office.  They were terrified about that because they were worried I was going to get hurt in the process.  So my parents did not live to see me run for office.  And so, you know, of course, that's very sad when you look back at it because they're the reasons I ran.  They're where my confidence, you know, comes from.  And that's one of the reasons I work on foster care.  And actually, I got involved in foster care because of crack cocaine because it was one of the first times that we had a drug epidemic where women used equally to men.  families fell apart and kids were placed in foster care.  These grandmothers called our organization and said, hey, I was awakened by social workers who told me that they were going to drop off my grandkids and my daughter was addicted to drugs and I don't know what to do and there's no resources.  So we started organizing those grandmothers and we took them to the board of supervisors and we fought for them to have benefits.  And so we really had to fight to change that system.  And I've been fighting to change that system ever since.  So the story of my life and different positions that I have had over the years have really been a matter of evolution as opposed to ambition.

I hear a life well lived, and if someone were just tuning in, and they were to see your smile, and they were to see you talk with this good, fresh energy about these various issues, they might easily assume that it's been a straight path, but I assume no one's had a perfect straight path.  Have there been big challenges for you along this road?

Sure.  All the time.  All the time there's been big challenges.  But I think the challenges in my life have been more personal.  Certainly because of my medical background, I took care of my parents.  And I was so proud to do that, I really was.  I mean, they helped support me learn medicine and the idea that I got to care for them in their later years was a source of tremendous pride.  My stepdaughter at a young age developed leukemia and we went through two and a half years of chemotherapy.  And then my biological daughter and son-in-law I lost when they were 23 years old.  Fresh out of college, just married.  A few months later after they were married, they were in a car accident, and I lost both of them.  And so I've had, you know, those are major, major, major challenges.
How does one come back from something like you just described with your daughter and your son-in-law?

Well, you know, I mean, it changes you forever, that's for sure.  My daughter and son-in-law were the center of my life, and to have that disappear on you overnight... is very traumatic.  But you carry on.  You don't ever get over it.  But I think part of what allowed me to continue was just thinking of her, because she would have been very upset with me if I didn't continue.

It's funny, as you were saying that Vice President Biden has talked to me before about losing family to a car accident unexpectedly.  And have you and he ever talked about that, which has impacted both of you?

Yes, you know, the most difficult part of it was, and it was the same with him, is when those accidents happened, both of us were in public life.  So you don't have an opportunity to grieve privately.  The world is watching you as you're grieving.  But I did have an opportunity to share with him something that really struck me.  When he was... uh being nominated to be the vice president.  in 08 they did this videotape of him and in the videotape talks about his wife and daughter and the accident.

something bad happened and i knew.  i don't know how i knew but the call said my wife was dead my daughter was dead and I wasn't sure how my sons were gonna make it.  For the first time in my life, I understood how someone could consciously decide to commit suicide.  Not because they were deranged, not because they were nuts, because they'd been to the top of the mountain, and they just knew in their heart they'd never get there again.

And that was a real profound moment for me because that accident was decades ago, but it was still up front and center a part of the narrative of his life.  And it made me realize from that moment on that what happened to my daughter and son-in-law was always gonna be a part of the narrative of my life when people talked about it.

You really are giving me pause there, and probably a lot of other people who probably don't realize what they are doing when they do that.  But I appreciate the point that you're making.  Congresswoman, I've talked to people before who all of a sudden were nominated for the vice presidency, and they said, as much as you think you're prepared for it, it's a shock to the system, especially up front.  Would you be okay with that level of scrutiny and spotlight?
In a way, I think you're never prepared.  But, you know, honest and truly, I feel like having gone through the shock of losing my daughter and son-in-law, nothing else could happen to me.  I mean.
Yeah, that makes sense.  Congresswoman, finally, what, if anything, can you teach other people about how to not only dream big but realize those dreams?

Well, I think it's about, one, not being afraid and being willing to take a risk and being willing to fail.  I mean, I've failed lots of times with different things that I wanted to do and sometimes a bit of grandiosity.  Yeah.  you know, didn't work out.  And it's also, you know, managing your ego.  I think the minute your ego gets involved, it just gets messy.  So for me, focusing on social and economic justice is not about my personal ego.
I'm going to shift away from politics just for a second and wrap up by doing a couple of rapid fire questions, if you don't mind.  Sure.  What's your favorite kind of music?
Rhythm and blues and gospel.  I love gospel music.
Oh, interesting.  Any favorite bands or performers in either case?
You know, I like the music of my youth, which means Motown.

Love that.  Okay.  What would surprise people to know about you?  What would absolutely surprise those folks who think they know Congresswoman Karen Bass?  What would surprise them to find out about her?
I spent several years studying martial arts.  Maybe that would be.
Oh, judo or karate or which one?
I studied Taekwondo and Hapkido, two Korean arts.  I earned brown belts in both.
And have you used those on the house floor or not yet?

No, but I will tell you that when I was speaker, not in terms of physical fighting, but there's a lot of the mental part of martial arts that you learn.  And you learn how to navigate conflicts.  And one of the goals of a martial artist is to not fight.
Thank you so much for joining us here on the show.  And I hope this will be the first but not the last.
Absolutely.  Thanks for having me on.

I was so excited about Congresswoman Karen Bass joining us.  For those of you who don't know, I've done a lot of politics over the years, met a lot of people on every side of the aisle.  But Congresswoman Bass has always been one of my favorites from the first time I met her.  And I don't know whether that's just her warmth, her intelligence, the fact that I just felt like there was a real commitment there, but I've always been a big fan.  and always said to people who would listen, if there's ever another Democratic Speaker of the House after Speaker Pelosi retires, I think it will be Congresswoman Bass.  I think she's that special.  But guess what?  Tonight, maybe we saw the next vice president, or at least the next vice presidential nominee.  Who knows?  But it was really interesting to hear.  And sometimes, sometimes in life, an interesting fit and interesting overlap leads to something special.  I hope you enjoyed today.  If you did, definitely tell people about it.  And more importantly, come back tomorrow because if today was good, tomorrow's going to be great.  See you then.  Take care.  Hey, tune into The Carlos Watson Show.  It's like no other.  You're going to enjoy it every weekday on YouTube.
